questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with weight loss, early satiety, and persistent upper abdominal discomfort for the past 2 months. He has a history of gastric carcinoma in a first-degree relative. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the CT findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and CT, the most probable diagnosis would be Linitis plastica

  • The CT scan image shows a Diffusely infiltrative gastric adenocarcinoma causing stiffening and diffuse thickening of the gastric wall that results in the linitis plastica pattern.

Linitis Plastica

  • Definition: A subtype of diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma that infiltrates the submucosa and muscularis propria.
  • CT Findings:
    • Diffuse circumferential thickening of the stomach wall
    • Loss of gastric rugal folds
    • Poor distensibility of the stomach ("leather bottle stomach")
    • Often involves antrum and body

  • Clinical Features:
    • Early satiety
    • Weight loss
    • Poor prognosis

Explanation of Other Options:

GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor) (Option A):

  • Definition: Mesenchymal tumor arising from the interstitial cells of Cajal.
  • CT Findings:
    • Well-defined mass, often exophytic
    • Can show central necrosis or cavitation
    • Typically arises from the stomach or small bowel
    • No diffuse wall thickening

Gastric Polyp (Option C):

  • Definition: Mucosal protrusion into the gastric lumen; can be adenomatous or hyperplastic.
  • CT Findings:
    • Small, round, intraluminal soft-tissue density
    • Usually non-infiltrative
    • May enhance mildly with contrast

Intestinal-type Gastric Carcinoma (Option D):

  • Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma; often forms an ulcerating mass.
  • CT Features:
    • Localized, irregular mass or ulcerated lesion.
    • More often affects the antrum or lesser curvature.
    • May cause focal wall thickening, but not the diffuse rigidity of linitis plastica.
  • Associated with intestinal metaplasia and chronic gastritis.
  • Has a better prognosis than diffuse type (linitis plastica).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can lead to the production of the image shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT scan image shows intramural air (air within the bowel wall) called pneumatosis intestinalis, here is evidence of hypoenhancing or non-enhancing wall of the intestines, and in advanced cases, there is the presence of air within the bowel walls
  • Acute mesenteric ischemia is caused by mesenteric arterial or venous narrowing or occlusion, causing inadequate perfusion of the bowel. The majority of cases are related to arterial occlusion with embolic (atrial fibrillation, endocarditis) and atherosclerotic events being the most common cause.
  • On CT Scan, there is evidence of hypoenhancing or non-enhancing wall of the intestines, and in advanced cases, there is the presence of air within the bowel walls(pneumatosis intestinalis).
  • Ischemia leads to mucosal injury → gas-forming bacteria enter the wall.
  • Can lead to bowel necrosis, portal venous gas, and perforation.
  • Suggestive CT findings include clots within the superior mesenteric artery, the superior mesenteric vein, or mesenteric vessels, diminished or absent mural enhancement
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis is a late and commonly irreversible finding in ischemia, suggestive of infarction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Peptic Ulcer (Option B):

  • Typically affects the stomach or duodenum, not the bowel wall.
  • Can cause free air in the peritoneum (pneumoperitoneum) due to perforation, but not pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • CT Findings: Localized wall thickening, free air or fluid if perforated.

Carcinoma (Option C):

  • Intestinal or colonic tumors can cause luminal obstruction or thickening.
  • Rarely associated with pneumatosis unless complicated by ischemia or superinfection.
  • CT Findings: Soft-tissue mass, wall thickening, possible obstruction, but no gas in the bowel wall.

Volvulus (Option D):

  • Twisting of the bowel, which may cause closed-loop obstruction.
  • Can lead to ischemia, and in late or severe cases, may cause pneumatosis - but it's not the primary finding.
  • CT Findings:
    • Whirl sign
    • Distended loops
    • Mesenteric twisting
    • Pneumatosis only if infarcted.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the supine abdominal radiograph?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X ray shows a large, gas filled dilated bowel which is located in LUQ which is suggestive of Caecal volvulus

Caecal volvulus

  • Torsion of the caecum, ascending colon, and terminal ileum, usually around the mesentery.
  • Most common in the mobile caecum.

Radiographic clues (supine X-ray):

  • Single large, gas-filled loop (dilated caecum).
  • Located in mid-abdomen or LUQ (displaced from RLQ).
  • Kidney-shaped or coffee-bean sign, but more central or LUQ compared to sigmoid volvulus.
  • Absent gas in the rectum and distal colon.

Distinguishing between sigmoid and caecal volvulus on plain films requires paying attention to the location, shape, and direction of the apex of the dilated loop.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sigmoid Volvulus (Option A):

  • Torsion of the sigmoid colon is more common in elderly or constipated patients.
  • Radiographic findings:
    • Inverted U-shaped, massively dilated loop.
    • Extends from the pelvis toward the diaphragm (often in LUQ or RUQ).
    • Apex points upward, usually midline or left upper quadrant.
    • "Coffee bean sign"s is classic, but location and orientation help differentiate it from caecal volvulus.

Small Intestinal Volvulus (Option C):

  • Twisting of small bowel loops; rare on plain films unless advanced.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Multiple dilated central loops of small bowel.
    • Air-fluid levels on erect film.
    • May show a stacked coin or "step-ladder" pattern.
    • Pneumatosis or free air if ischemia/perforation.
  • No single large dilated loop as in sigmoid/caecal volvulus.

Gastric Volvulus (OptionD):

  • Twisting of the stomach, typically along the long (organoaxial) or short axis.
  • Usually diagnosed with an upper GI contrast study or CT.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Massively distended stomach with an air-fluid level in LUQ.
    • Two air-fluid levels in some cases.
    • No bowel gas or classic volvulus appearance like sigmoid or caecal volvulus.

questions.text: Given below is an MRCP image of a patient with a complaint of jaundice. It is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRCP shows beaded appearance of bile duct which is the characteristic finding of primary sclerosis cholangitis.

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an inflammatory condition that affects the biliary tree, resulting in multiple strictures
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), especially ulcerative colitis,
  • The characteristic findings on direct imaging of the biliary tree are: multiple segmental strictures and dilatations

questions.text: What is the procedure that includes sterile cannulation of the peripheral biliary radicle after percutaneous puncture, followed by imaging-guided wire and catheter manipulation and placement of a tube or stent for external and/or internal drainage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage is the procedure that includes sterile cannulation of the peripheral biliary radicle after percutaneous puncture, followed by imaging-guided wire and catheter manipulation and placement of a tube or stent for external and/or internal drainage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Percutaneous cholecystostomy(Option A): It is a procedure where a catheter is inserted through the skin directly into the gallbladder to drain bile externally. It is typically done to relieve infection or inflammation in the gallbladder, such as in acute cholecystitis, especially when surgery is not feasible. This procedure does not involve accessing the intrahepatic bile ducts or placing stents inside the biliary tree. Instead, it targets the gallbladder specifically and provides external drainage of bile.

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC)(Option C): It is a diagnostic imaging procedure where a peripheral bile duct is punctured percutaneously, and contrast dye is injected to visualize the biliary tree under fluoroscopy. This helps identify strictures, stones, or other causes of bile duct obstruction. However, PTC does not involve placing drainage tubes or stents; it is purely for visualization and diagnosis. Therapeutic interventions, if needed, typically follow with PTBD.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presented with right upper abdominal pain. She has a history of calculus within the gall bladder for 40 years. On doing a USG, the following image is obtained of the liver and the GB. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given image, there is a mass in the gall bladder and a hypoechoic lesion within the liver, giving the target appearance; suggestive of metastasis.

Common in elderly females with longstanding gallstones, which is a major risk factor.

The most common type: is adenocarcinoma.

Ultrasound findings:

  • Mass replacing or infiltrating the gallbladder wall.
  • Irregular wall thickening (focal or diffuse).
  • May have adjacent liver lesions → suggestive of hepatic metastasis.
  • Loss of the fat plane between the GB and the liver.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gallbladder Calculus (Option A):

  • Very common; typically asymptomatic or causes biliary colic.
  • USG appearance:
    • Echogenic focus with posterior acoustic shadowing.
    • No soft tissue mass.
    • Gallbladder wall is usually normal or thickened in cholecystitis, but not invaded.

Gallbladder Polyp (Option C):

  • Usually benign (e.g., cholesterol polyp); adenomas are precancerous but rare.
  • USG findings:
    • Non-shadowing, immobile intraluminal soft tissue lesion.
    • Typically <10 mm, attached to the GB wall by a narrow stalk.
    • No liver involvement or mass effect.

Gallbladder Perforation (Option D):

  • Complications of acute cholecystitis or trauma.
  • USG findings:
    • Discontinuity in the GB wall.
    • Pericholecystic fluid or abscess.
    • Possibly gallstones outside the gallbladder.

questions.text: A young athlete presented with right upper quadrant pain. He has a history of steroid intake. On doing a CT scan , the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the history of steroid intake, right upper quadrant pain, and typical CT features, appears as a well-defined lesion, hepatic adenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

  • Hepatic adenomas are benign, generally hormone-induced liver tumors.
  • The tumors are usually solitary, and have a predilection for hemorrhage.

Predisposing Risk factors include

  • oral contraceptive use (especially the first-generation pills, which have a high concentration of estrogens)
  • Anabolic steroids: typically young men
  • Glycogen storage diseases
  • obesity
  • metabolic syndrome
  • diabetes mellitus

CT Findings:

  • Arterial phase: Homogeneous hyperenhancement
  • Portal venous phase: Washout (becomes hypodense relative to the liver)
  • No central scar

Explanation of Other Options:

Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH) ( Option A):

  • Benign hyperplastic lesion, common in young women
  • CT Findings:
    • Strong arterial enhancement
    • Iso- to hyperdense in portal and delayed phases (no washout)
    • The central scar that enhances delayed images (fibrous)

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) ( Option B):

  • Malignant liver tumors, usually in cirrhotic livers
  • CT Findings:
    • Arterial phase hyperenhancement
    • Washout in the portal/delayed phases
    • May have capsule, mosaic architecture, or invasion

Liver Abscess ( Option D):

  • Infectious, presents with fever, leukocytosis, right upper quadrant tenderness
  • CT Findings:
    • Hypodense lesion, often rim-enhancing ("double target sign")
    • May contain gas
    • No arterial phase enhancement like a solid tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, weight loss, and early satiety for the past 3 months. A barium meal study is performed, which shows a large ulcer with a meniscus-shaped collection of barium surrounded by a radiolucent halo within the stomach. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological sign described
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The radiological sign described in the case is the Carman meniscus sign, which is seen in malignant ulcer

  • The Carman meniscus sign refers to a barium-filled ulcer crater surrounded by nodular or irregular heaped-up edges forming a meniscus-like shape.
  • Seen on barium meal in gastric carcinoma with central ulceration.
  • The ulcer projects within a mass, and the radiolucent halo represents infiltrated surrounding mucosa.

Explanation of Other Options:

Benign Ulcer (Option A):

  • Typically punched-out, with radiating mucosal folds extending to the ulcer base.
  • Located usually on the lesser curvature.
  • Benign Gastric Ulcer shows an Ulcer collar and Hampton line on barium study.

Stricture (Option C):

  • Appears as a narrowed segment, often due to chronic ulceration or malignancy.
  • No meniscus; instead, there is a constricted lumen.
  • Commonly seen in pyloric stenosis.

Perforation (Option D):

  • Typically diagnosed by free air under the diaphragm on X-ray or CT scan.

questions.text: 'Pseudosacculation' on imaging is a feature of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudosacculation refers to sacculation or outpouchings that appear on imaging due to asymmetric fibrosis and scarring of the intestinal wall.
  • These are not true diverticula but rather result from the normal mucosa bulging between contracted fibrotic segments.
  • Commonly seen in barium studies or CT enterography in chronic Crohn's disease.
  • Pseudodiverticula/pseudosacculation formation is seen due to contraction at the site of the ulcer with ballooning of the opposite (usually antimesenteric) side in Crohn's Disease.

Other Radiological Features of Crohn's Disease:

Explanation of Other Options:

Ulcerative Colitis ( Option A):

  • Involves the mucosa and submucosa, continuous from the rectum.
  • Radiological findings:
    • Lead pipe colon (loss of haustra)
    • Collar button ulcers
    • Superficial mucosal ulcerations

Stricture (Option C):

  • It can occur in Crohn's, tuberculosis, ischemia, or post-radiation.
  • Appears as a narrowed segment on imaging.
  • No sacculations are seen, unless secondary to underlying Crohn's (where pseudo sacculation might coexist).

Carcinoma (Option D):

  • Typically presents as:
    • Apple-core lesion on barium study
    • Asymmetric wall thickening
    • Shouldered edges, irregular mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following modalities is now preferred for pretreatment staging of rectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MRI is the modality of choice for rectal cancer staging. The high soft-tissue contrast of MRI accurately assesses the extramural tumor spread and its relation to mesorectal fascia and the sphincter complex.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for staging rectal cancer to assist surgeons in obtaining negative surgical margins.
  • MRI facilitates the accurate assessment of mesorectal fascia and the sphincter complex for surgical planning.

questions.text: On endoscopic ultrasound, the mucosa is seen as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mucosa is seen as a hyperechoic structure on endoscopic USG.

  • Superficial Mucosa: Appears as a hyperechoic (bright) layer.
  • Deep Mucosa: Appears as a hypoechoic (dark) layer.
  • Submucosa: The third layer, which is hyperechoic.
  • Muscularis Propria: The fourth hypoechoic layer.
  • Adventitia/Serosa: The fifth layer, which is hyperechoic.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities helps in differentiating the T1 and T2 stages of colorectal tumors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) provides excellent resolution, and the layers of the bowel can be differentiated.
  • This helps in differentiating the T1 and T2 stages of the tumor and thus changing the management of the tumor.

T1 tumor: Invades submucosa

T2 tumor: Invades muscularis propria

EUS provides high-resolution imaging of bowel wall layers, allowing accurate distinction of depth of invasion:

  • Accuracy for T-staging: ~85-90%
  • Especially useful for rectal cancers

Explanation of Other Options:

CT Scan (Option A): Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis plays a key role in staging colorectal cancer, offering good assessment for T3/T4 tumors but limited accuracy for differentiating T1/T2 lesions; while it is effective in detecting metastases to the liver, lungs, and peritoneum, its nodal evaluation is limited due to reliance on size and morphology, and it cannot accurately distinguish the individual layers of the bowel wall.

CT is the workhorse for metastatic workup, but not ideal for early local staging.

MRI (Option B): MRI, especially useful for rectal tumors, provides excellent T-staging by distinguishing T2 from T3 lesions and is crucial for assessing mesorectal fascia involvement for surgical planning; nodal staging is based on lymph node size, border irregularity, and signal intensity, though MRI is less effective for evaluating the small bowel and colon compared to the rectum. MRI is the modality of choice for rectal cancer staging due to its soft tissue resolution.

Barium enema(Option D): It is a contrast study that outlines the colon's lumen but cannot assess the depth of tumor invasion, making it unsuitable for differentiating T1 and T2 stages of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: Which bowel loops are seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The jejunum is defined as the proximal two-fifths of the small intestine. Compared to the ileum, the jejunum has more valvulae conniventes
  • Jejunum has a delicate feathery appearance and is located in the left upper abdomen. The given image shows valvulae conniventes and is suggestive of the jejunum.

questions.text: Invertogram is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The invertogram view is a radiograph often used exclusively in characterizing anal atresia in paediatric population.
  • It should be done 24 hrs after birth

Invertogram (Wangensteen-Rice method) is a lateral radiograph taken 6-12 hours after birth with a radiopaque marker at the anal dimple.

Helps differentiate:

  • High-type Anorectal malformation: Rectal gas >2 cm above the perineal marker.
  • Low-type norectal malformation: Rectal gas close to or below the perineal skin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intestinal Obstruction (Option A):

  • May be evaluated by plain abdominal X-ray or contrast studies (e.g., barium enema).
  • Presents with vomiting and distension, not imperforate anus.

Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) (Option C):

  • Diagnosed via abdominal X-ray showing:
    • Pneumatosis intestinalis
    • Portal venous gas
    • Free air (if perforated)

Hirschsprung Disease (Option D): Hirschsprung disease is diagnosed using a contrast enema (showing a transition zone) and confirmed by rectal biopsy. Invertogram is not used in its diagnosis or evaluation.

questions.text: A newborn infant presents within the first few hours of life with persistent non-bilious vomiting and upper abdominal distension. There is no passage of meconium since birth. A supine abdominal X-ray is obtained, which shows a characteristic double bubble appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical case and X-ray findings, the most probable diagnosis would be Duodenal atresia

  • The double bubble sign is seen in infants and represents dilatation of the proximal duodenum and stomach. It is seen in both radiographs and ultrasound.
  • No distal gas → complete obstruction.
  • Typically presents soon after birth with bilious or non-bilious vomiting, depending on location.
  • Commonly associated with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

Double bubble sign is seen in the following cases:

  • duodenal web
  • duodenal atresia
  • duodenal stenosis
  • annular pancreas
  • Ladd bands

Explanation of Other Options:

Ileal Atresia (Option C):

  • Obstruction is more distal, so multiple air-fluid levels are seen.
  • Gas is usually present in the stomach, duodenum, and proximal small bowel.
  • Does not show a "double bubble" sign.
  • Presents with bilious vomiting and a distended abdomen.
